body.p: Match the neuron type to its classification.

response.feedback: Correct. The “uni-“ prefix here refers to the single cellular extension from the cell body, even though one branch of it functions as a dendrite.
Incorrect. The “bi-“ prefix is a hint about the number of cellular extensions from the soma or neuron cell body.
Incorrect. The “multi-“ prefix is a hint about the number of cellular extensions from the soma or neuron cell body.
Incorrect. The “ana-“ prefix (meaning without) is a hint about the number of cellular extensions that can be anatomically recognized as being an axon.
Incorrect. “Afferent” in Latin means “to bring toward” as a functional classification; in this case think of the central nervous system as the “center”.
Incorrect. “Inter” means in-between the other functions of neurons; in this case think of the central nervous system as the “center”.
Incorrect. “Efferent” in Latin means “to carry away” as a functional classification; in this case think of the central nervous system as the “center.”

part.hint: The structural classification of neurons depends on the number and types of cytoplasmic extensions and the name includes hints about this. The functional classification of neurons depends on the location (CNS or PNS) and direction of different kinds of nerve impulses.
